channel.title: Ring_Theory on MathWiki
channel.description: Recent content in Ring_Theory on MathWiki

item.title: Integers
item.description: The set of integers, denoted $\Z$, appear everywhere in algebra: In group theory, it is the free group on one generator, and is used to construct all cyclic groups, and more generally, all finitely-generated abelian groups. The latter claim follows from the Structure Theorem. In ring theory, it is the initial object in $\catring$, and is the most important example of a PID. In fact, abelian groups are just $\Z$-modules, and rings are just $\Z$-algebras.
